Authors:
Olivier Maurin, A. Muthama Muasya, Pilar Catalan, EUGENE Z
Shongwe, JUAN Viruel, P. Wilkin, Michelle van der Bank
Title:
Diversification into novel habitats in the southern African
clade of Dioscorea (Dioscoreaceae): erect habit and elephants foot
tubers
Keywords:
Dioscoreales, Southern Africa, Pachycaul, “elephants
foot”, Biogeography, Habitat transition, Fire adaptation.
Abstract:
Dioscorea, a widely distributed and highly diversified
genus in tropical regions, is represented by ten main clades. In
southern Africa it is characterised by a distinct group with a pachycaul
or “elephants foot” structure, which is partially to fully exposed from
the substrate. In contrast to other African representative of the genus,
which are mostly occurring in forest or woodland vegetation, the
pachycaul taxa occurs in a diversity of habitats ranging from woodland
to open vegetation. Here we investigate patterns of diversification of
the African clade, time of transition from forest to more open habitat,
morphological traits associated to each habitat and evaluate if such
transition has lead to modification of reproductive organs and mode of
dispersion. The African clade originated in the Oligocene and comprises
four clades, with the Eastern African clade sister to the three
predominantly South African clades (basally lobed leaves, Cape and
pachycaul clades). In mid Miocene, the Cape and pachycaul clades
originated and diversified in the east of the Cape, in an area with
complex geomorphology and climate, where the fynbos, thicket, succulent
karoo and forest biomes meet. Diversification out of the forest is
associated in shift morphology of tuber (annual tuber to perennial tuber
which becomes a pachycaul), stem (from twining to non-twining), seed
(loss of wings and enlarged aril), and floral morphology.
